title: Manchester United chief Ed Woodward insists club is ‘committed to winning trophies’ after record revenues
text:
Ed Woodward has insisted that everyone at Manchester United is ‘committed to winning trophies’ despite the club’s difficult start to the Premier League season.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s side have taken just eight points from their first six games, having suffered their second defeat of the campaign on Sunday against West Ham.

United spent approximately £140m on three new players during the summer, but there remains unrest among supporters following last season’s sixth-place finish.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Upon the announcement of record revenues of £627.1m, United’s executive vice-chairman reiterated that the club is engaged in a rebuilding process under Solskjaer.

“We remain focused on our plan of rebuilding the team and continuing to strengthen our youth system, in line with the philosophy of the club and the manager,” Woodward said.

“This is reflected in the recent addition of three exciting first team players, key player contract extensions and the talent we have coming through our academy.”

Woodward added: “Everyone at Manchester United is committed to delivering on our primary objective of winning trophies.”

The remarks echo those made by a United spokesperson in a recent fans’ forum, when the club stressed that their focus is not profit but success on the pitch.

United’s £627.1m in revenues for the 2018-19 season was a record, with an increase of around 6 per cent from 2017-18, predominantly due to an increase in broadcast income from Champions League rights.

Failure to qualify for the Champions League last season will result in reduction in revenues, when revenues are expected to range between £560m to £580m

The club’s wage bill increased to £332.3m last year, approximately a 12 per cent hike on the previous year and 53 per cent of turnover.
description: Ed Woodward has insisted that everyone at Manchester United is ‘committed to winning trophies’ despite the club’s difficult start to the Premier League season. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s side have taken just eight points from their first six games, having suffered their second defeat of the campaign on Sunday against West Ham.
